Award.AwardTitle: Improving the Pipeline: After-School Model for Preparing Cyber Defense and Information Assurance Professionals

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project addresses a need to educate more information assurance/cyber defense (IA/CD) professionals to counteract the growing risk of cyber-attacks. The project does so by developing and implementing an IA/CD after-school program for high school students and assessing its effectiveness as a launchpad for IA/CD careers. The program goals are to raise awareness of high school students about IA/CD careers; generate their interest in those careers; and solidify and enhance the preparation of participating students to pursue the education required to succeed in one of those careers. Once fully implemented, the program will annually enroll up to 50 students from five local rural high schools. Because of high demand for IA/CD specialists, those who continue on to complete the degree program will be able to secure well-paying jobs, which will have economic impact not only on them, but also on their families and communities. The program will also train teachers in participating schools to become more knowledgeable and aware of information security issues. The teachers will pass this knowledge on to their students and families, thereby improving information security among the general public.

The project will advance both knowledge and education in the field of cybersecurity by examining the conditions that impact high school students' decisions to pursue IA/CD careers and their success in an academic program that leads to these careers. The evaluation will also examine the project's ability to attract students underrepresented in the profession-female, first-generation, and low-income students. The rigorous evaluation plan will gauge the effectiveness of specific components, particularly the modular after-school academic program, the hands-on cyber competitions, Penn College student mentoring and coaching provided by professionals in the field. By documenting all project elements, publishing and presenting program results and lessons learned, and making program information available on the project website and via seminars and webinars, the Project Team will make this model available to institutions interested in replicating or adapting it. The specific objectives of the project are to: (1) develop an after-school college credit-bearing program in IA/CD for high school students; (2) provide the after-school program to 8-10 students in Year 1, 24-30 students in Year 2, and 40-50 students in Year 3; and (3) research the impact of the proposed model on students' educational and career choices/paths.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed new activities aimed at developing a pipeline of high school students interested in pursuing cybersecurity related careers. Activities included developing a credit-bearing, afterschool college-level course open to area high school students with no prerequisite knowledge of computing. This was accomplished through a ?just-in-time? delivery model, virtualization, and the novel use of a new Cybersecurity Lab in a Box, which enabled students to engage in hands-on activities such as network building, simple cryptography, and ethical hacking in a safe environment.

Throughout the grant, 43 of 49 (88%) local high school students completed the program. Among this cohort, 20% eventually enrolled in academic programs at Pennsylvania College of Technology. Additionally, 3 students (6%) enrolled in cybersecurity related programs (two at Penn College, one elsewhere), and 4 more chose other college majors in computing. This represents 14% of the program participants choosing computing-related majors overall. While it?s unlikely all 7 students who chose a computing major were first exposed to the field while enrolled in the program, it does likely indicate that the program did provide a positive effect on some students? decision to enroll. This is further supported by student qualitative feedback that indicated the course was helpful for all students, despite future college/career plans. Furthermore, educators from 17 other institutions (K12 and postsecondary) have expressed a desire to review our course materials for consideration of adopting the program at other locations.

The academic success of the high school students (average GPA for the course was 3.07) further provides evidence that the just-in-time educational model for teaching computing concepts (i.e. programming, networking, etc.) is viable. This, combined with the qualitative results described above, has led the project team to develop a new three-credit college course open to the entire campus community. Introduction to Cybersecurity for Non-IT majors uses the strategies, methods, and materials developed during the project period to familiarize students from all majors to the concepts of cybersecurity. The new course fulfills a technological literacy general education requirement for Penn College students, and as such, will hopefully be adopted by other academic majors at the institution. While this doesn?t directly increase the pipeline of qualified cybersecurity technicians, it provides a greater understanding of the concepts and concerns in this area to a larger student population. In turn, students will hopefully be more security savvy and serve as a critical, and well-informed, component of the overall employment marketplace.
